author: Jack Broom
title: Weather service issues ‘red flag warning’ in North Cascades
text:
Firefighters in the North Cascades are facing some of the most difficult conditions nature can dish out — and Friday is expected to be worse — according to a “red flag warning” issued by the National Weather Service Thursday.
“This is going to be a critical weather situation,” and could set the stage for the kind of fast-moving blaze “that just nukes everything in its path,” said Weather Service fire weather forecaster Andy Haner in Seattle.
Gusts of up to 50 mph, and sustained winds of 30 mph, are expected through Friday afternoon in the Okanogan Valley, weather that could help existing fires move rapidly.
“All of Eastern Washington is going to be windy, but the Okanogan Valley is expected to have the strongest winds,” Haner said.
Most Read Stories Wind-whipped wildfire kills 3 firefighters, injures 4 near Twisp No bodies found in wreckage of Bremerton motel Cascadia fault chatters and pops with little quakes When fire chief called for help, and no one was left State cracks down on fraudulent immigration aid When winds are calm and a fire moves through low vegetation, fire crews can attempt to clear fuels out of its path. But Haner said high winds spread fire through the crowns of trees, allowing flames to pick up speed as they race up ridges or down valleys.
The Weather Service advisory calls for “extreme fire growth potential” through much of the Cascades east of the summit.
Haner passed along the assessment he heard Thursday from one of his counterparts in Eastern Washington: “To say it’s going to be a mess is an understatement “
